factors: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

items.text: I feel a constant sense of dread that something terrible is about to happen, even when everything seems fine.
items.rationale: Pervasive apprehensive expectation is a hallmark of generalized anxiety disorder.

items.text: My heart races, I can't breathe, and I feel like I'm dying — these episodes come out of nowhere.
items.rationale: Describes classic unexpected panic attacks with somatic and cognitive symptoms.

items.text: I avoid social situations because I'm terrified people will judge me or think I'm stupid.
items.rationale: Core feature of social anxiety disorder — fear of negative evaluation leading to avoidance.

items.text: I can't stop checking the locks on my doors, even though I know I already checked them five times.
items.rationale: Repetitive checking compulsions driven by obsessional doubt are characteristic of OCD.

items.text: Ever since the accident, I have nightmares about it almost every night and I can't drive past the intersection where it happened.
items.rationale: Re-experiencing and avoidance symptoms following a traumatic event are core PTSD features.

items.text: I worry excessively about my health, my finances, my family — I can never seem to turn off the worry.
items.rationale: Excessive, difficult-to-control worry across multiple domains defines generalized anxiety disorder.

items.text: Being in crowded places or on public transportation makes me feel trapped, and I have to leave immediately.
items.rationale: Agoraphobic avoidance of situations where escape might be difficult is a key diagnostic feature.

items.text: I have intrusive, unwanted thoughts about harming people I love, even though I would never act on them.
items.rationale: Ego-dystonic intrusive thoughts of harm are a common obsessional theme in OCD.

items.text: I've been unable to speak in school for years, even though I talk normally at home with my family.
items.rationale: Consistent failure to speak in specific social situations despite speaking in others defines selective mutism.

items.text: She becomes extremely distressed whenever she has to be away from her mother, even for a few hours.
items.rationale: Excessive distress upon separation from attachment figures is the core of separation anxiety disorder.

items.text: I tense up my whole body without realizing it, and by the end of the day my muscles are aching from the tension.
items.rationale: Chronic muscle tension is a somatic hallmark of generalized anxiety disorder.

items.text: I have an intense, irrational fear of spiders that I know is out of proportion, but I can't control it.
items.rationale: Marked, disproportionate fear of a specific object with insight defines specific phobia.

items.text: I lie awake at night running through every possible thing that could go wrong tomorrow.
items.rationale: Ruminative worry and insomnia are common in anxiety but also occur in depressive disorders.

items.text: I feel on edge all the time and I startle at the slightest unexpected noise.
items.rationale: Hyperarousal and exaggerated startle are seen in anxiety disorders and PTSD, but can overlap with hypervigilance in other conditions.

items.text: I can't stop worrying and I've lost interest in things I used to enjoy — everything feels hopeless.
items.rationale: Persistent worry maps to anxiety, but anhedonia and hopelessness are cardinal depressive symptoms, suggesting comorbid or primary depressive disorder.

items.text: There was a week where I slept only two hours a night, started three new business ventures, and felt absolutely invincible.
items.rationale: Decreased need for sleep, grandiosity, and increased goal-directed activity are classic manic episode criteria.

items.text: My mood can swing from feeling on top of the world to being in the deepest depression within the same month.
items.rationale: Cycling between elevated and depressed mood states is the defining pattern of bipolar disorder.

items.text: During those episodes, I spend thousands of dollars I don't have on things I don't need and don't even remember buying.
items.rationale: Excessive involvement in activities with high potential for painful consequences (spending sprees) is a DSM criterion for mania.

items.text: He talks so fast during these periods that no one can follow his train of thought — he jumps from topic to topic.
items.rationale: Pressured speech and flight of ideas are hallmark symptoms of a manic episode.

items.text: I felt so energized and confident that I quit my job, booked a flight to another country, and proposed to someone I'd known for two days.
items.rationale: Impulsive, grandiose decisions with significant consequences during an elevated mood state are characteristic of mania.

items.text: For about four days I felt unusually upbeat and productive — I didn't need much sleep but I could still function at work.
items.rationale: A distinct period of elevated mood lasting at least four days without severe impairment describes a hypomanic episode (Bipolar II).

items.text: She has had periods of elevated mood and depression for at least two years, but the highs never meet full criteria for hypomania.
items.rationale: Chronic fluctuating mood disturbance with subthreshold hypomanic and depressive periods defines cyclothymic disorder.

items.text: When I'm in that state, I believe I have special powers and a unique mission that only I can fulfill.
items.rationale: Grandiose delusions during mood episodes are consistent with bipolar disorder with psychotic features.

items.text: I went from needing only three hours of sleep and feeling fantastic to being unable to get out of bed for weeks.
items.rationale: The transition from decreased sleep need with euphoria to psychomotor retardation captures the bipolar mood cycle.

items.text: My doctor says the mood episodes started after I began taking a new antidepressant, but they've continued even after stopping it.
items.rationale: Substance/medication-induced mania that persists beyond physiological effects of the substance meets criteria for bipolar disorder.

items.text: During those high periods, I become hypersexual and engage in risky encounters that I deeply regret afterward.
items.rationale: Increased sexual drive with risky behavior during elevated mood is a recognized manic/hypomanic symptom.

items.text: He becomes extremely irritable and agitated rather than euphoric — he picks fights and can't sit still for a moment.
items.rationale: Irritable mood with psychomotor agitation is an alternative presentation of mania recognized in DSM-5.

items.text: I feel restless and agitated, and I've been making impulsive decisions I later regret.
items.rationale: Agitation and impulsivity occur in mania but also in agitated depression and impulse-control disorders.

items.text: Sometimes I feel incredibly creative and productive, and other times I can barely function — it's been like this for years.
items.rationale: Fluctuating productivity and functioning suggest cyclothymia or bipolar spectrum, but could reflect other mood or personality patterns.

items.text: I go through periods where I'm extremely irritable, can't sleep, and then crash into weeks of not wanting to live.
items.rationale: Irritability and insomnia could reflect an anxiety or depressive disorder; the cycling pattern and suicidality overlap with depressive disorders.

items.text: I've felt sad and empty nearly every day for the past two months, and nothing seems to bring me any pleasure.
items.rationale: Persistent depressed mood and anhedonia lasting at least two weeks are the cardinal symptoms of major depressive disorder.

items.text: I sleep twelve or more hours a day and still feel exhausted — even getting dressed feels like an enormous effort.
items.rationale: Hypersomnia and fatigue with psychomotor retardation are prominent neurovegetative symptoms of depression.

items.text: I feel worthless and like a burden to everyone around me — they'd be better off without me.
items.rationale: Feelings of worthlessness and perceived burdensomeness are core cognitive symptoms of major depression and risk factors for suicidality.

items.text: She has been in a low mood for most of the day, more days than not, for over two years now.
items.rationale: Chronically depressed mood for at least two years defines persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia).

items.text: I can't concentrate on anything — I read the same paragraph over and over and nothing registers.
items.rationale: Diminished ability to think or concentrate is a DSM-5 criterion for major depressive episode.

items.text: I've lost fifteen pounds in the last month without trying — I have no appetite at all.
items.rationale: Significant unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite are neurovegetative symptoms of depression.

items.text: Every morning I wake up feeling a heavy dread, and the sadness is worst in the early hours before it slightly lifts by evening.
items.rationale: Diurnal mood variation with morning worsening is a melancholic feature specifier of major depressive disorder.

items.text: I think about death constantly — not necessarily killing myself, but wishing I just wouldn't wake up.
items.rationale: Recurrent thoughts of death and passive suicidal ideation are DSM-5 criteria for major depressive episode.

items.text: Since having my baby, I've felt disconnected from her and overwhelmed by dark thoughts about harming myself.
items.rationale: Depressed mood, detachment, and suicidal ideation with peripartum onset describe major depressive disorder with peripartum onset specifier.

items.text: I feel guilty about things that happened years ago, and I can't stop blaming myself even though others tell me it wasn't my fault.
items.rationale: Excessive or inappropriate guilt is a core cognitive symptom of major depressive disorder.

items.text: He moves and speaks so slowly now — it's like watching someone in slow motion compared to how he used to be.
items.rationale: Observable psychomotor retardation is a DSM-5 criterion for major depressive episode.

items.text: Every winter I sink into a deep depression — I oversleep, overeat, and withdraw from everyone until spring.
items.rationale: Recurrent depressive episodes with seasonal pattern, atypical features (hypersomnia, hyperphagia) describe MDD with seasonal pattern specifier.

items.text: I feel irritable and short-tempered all the time, and the smallest things set me off into tears or rage.
items.rationale: Irritability can be a manifestation of depression, especially in certain populations, but also overlaps with bipolar mixed states and impulse-control disorders.

items.text: I've lost all motivation and I just go through the motions every day — nothing feels real or meaningful anymore.
items.rationale: Amotivation and derealization-like emptiness are common in depression but could also suggest dissociative or neurocognitive processes.

items.text: I feel persistently sad and I've been having angry outbursts where I destroy things and then feel terrible about it.
items.rationale: Persistent sadness maps to depression, but recurrent angry outbursts with destructive behavior could indicate disruptive mood dysregulation or impulse-control disorder.

items.text: I lose my temper over the smallest things and have explosive outbursts that are completely out of proportion to the situation.
items.rationale: Recurrent behavioral outbursts disproportionate to provocation are the defining feature of intermittent explosive disorder.

items.text: He has been setting fires deliberately since he was ten years old — he says he feels a rush of excitement before and relief after.
items.rationale: Deliberate fire-setting with tension beforehand and gratification afterward defines pyromania.

items.text: I shoplift things I don't even need or want — it's the thrill of taking them that I can't resist.
items.rationale: Recurrent failure to resist impulses to steal objects not needed for personal use or monetary value defines kleptomania.

items.text: She has been bullying other children, skipping school, and was caught breaking into a neighbor's car at age thirteen.
items.rationale: A pattern of aggression, deceitfulness, and rule violations in a minor is characteristic of conduct disorder.

items.text: He argues with every authority figure, deliberately annoys people, and blames others for all of his mistakes.
items.rationale: A pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, and vindictiveness defines oppositional defiant disorder.

items.text: I punched a hole in the wall and broke my hand because someone cut me off in traffic — I couldn't control myself.
items.rationale: Impulsive aggressive outbursts resulting in property destruction and self-injury are consistent with intermittent explosive disorder.

items.text: He has been cruel to animals on multiple occasions and shows no remorse when confronted about it.
items.rationale: Physical cruelty to animals is a DSM-5 criterion for conduct disorder under aggression to people and animals.

items.text: I get into physical fights at least twice a month — I know I shouldn't, but the anger just takes over.
items.rationale: Recurrent physical aggression with a sense of loss of control is a core feature of intermittent explosive disorder.

items.text: She has been suspended from school repeatedly for threatening teachers and refusing to follow any rules.
items.rationale: Persistent defiance of authority and threatening behavior in a school setting are consistent with ODD or conduct disorder.

items.text: He lies constantly, has stolen from family members, and has been truant from school for months.
items.rationale: Deceitfulness, theft, and serious rule violations are DSM-5 criteria for conduct disorder.

items.text: I feel a rising tension before I act on the urge, and then an immediate sense of relief or pleasure afterward.
items.rationale: The tension-action-relief cycle is the hallmark phenomenology of impulse-control disorders such as kleptomania and pyromania.

items.text: He has used a weapon to intimidate others and has forced someone into sexual activity.
items.rationale: Use of weapons and forced sexual activity are among the most severe conduct disorder criteria under aggression to people.

items.text: I feel angry and resentful most of the time, and I often go out of my way to get back at people who I think have wronged me.
items.rationale: Chronic anger and vindictiveness are features of ODD, but persistent resentment could also reflect personality pathology or depression.

items.text: I can't seem to stop myself from doing destructive things even though I know there will be consequences.
items.rationale: Failure to resist destructive impulses is central to impulse-control disorders but could also reflect mania or substance use.

items.text: I have intense anger outbursts followed by deep shame and sadness — I feel completely out of control of my emotions.
items.rationale: Explosive anger followed by shame could indicate intermittent explosive disorder, but the emotional dysregulation and shame cycle also suggests bipolar or depressive disorders.

items.text: Sometimes I suddenly find myself in a place with no memory of how I got there or what I've been doing for the past several hours.
items.rationale: Dissociative amnesia with dissociative fugue involves inability to recall autobiographical information, often involving unplanned travel.

items.text: I feel like I'm watching myself from outside my body, as if I'm an observer of my own life rather than a participant.
items.rationale: Persistent experiences of unreality or detachment from one's self define depersonalization in depersonalization/derealization disorder.

items.text: People tell me I've said or done things that I have absolutely no recollection of — it's as if someone else was in control.
items.rationale: Amnesia for one's own actions with a sense of external control is characteristic of dissociative identity disorder.

items.text: The world around me often looks foggy, dreamlike, or unreal, as though I'm looking at everything through a pane of glass.
items.rationale: Persistent derealization — experiencing surroundings as unreal or dreamlike — is a core feature of depersonalization/derealization disorder.

items.text: I have distinct identities that take control of my behavior, each with their own name, voice, and set of memories.
items.rationale: Disruption of identity characterized by two or more distinct personality states is the defining criterion of dissociative identity disorder.

items.text: There are large gaps in my memory for important personal events — entire years of my childhood are completely blank.
items.rationale: Inability to recall important autobiographical information, typically of a traumatic nature, defines dissociative amnesia.

items.text: I sometimes look in the mirror and don't recognize the person staring back at me — it feels like a stranger's face.
items.rationale: Failure to recognize one's own reflection is a vivid depersonalization experience seen in dissociative disorders.

items.text: My therapist noticed that my voice, posture, and mannerisms change dramatically during sessions, as if different people are present.
items.rationale: Observable shifts in identity states noted by a clinician are consistent with dissociative identity disorder.

items.text: I find writings, drawings, or purchases in my home that I don't remember creating or buying.
items.rationale: Evidence of actions performed during amnestic episodes is a common clinical presentation in dissociative identity disorder.

items.text: I feel emotionally numb, as though my feelings have been switched off — I can't feel joy, sadness, or anything at all.
items.rationale: Emotional numbing and detachment from one's affective experience are features of depersonalization.

items.text: After the trauma, I couldn't remember any details of what happened, even though I was fully conscious during the event.
items.rationale: Localized amnesia for a traumatic event is the most common form of dissociative amnesia.

items.text: I sometimes hear voices inside my head that feel like they belong to different parts of me arguing with each other.
items.rationale: Internal auditory pseudo-hallucinations experienced as different identity states are characteristic of DID, distinct from psychotic hallucinations.

items.text: My hands sometimes feel like they don't belong to me, as if they're made of rubber or are someone else's entirely.
items.rationale: Somatic depersonalization involving body parts feeling unreal is consistent with dissociative disorders but could overlap with neurological conditions.

items.text: I zone out so completely during stressful moments that I lose track of entire conversations and have no idea what was said.
items.rationale: Stress-related dissociative episodes with amnesia are common in dissociative disorders but could also reflect attentional deficits or anxiety.

items.text: I have periods where I can't remember what I did for several hours, and people say I seemed confused and wandered away from home.
items.rationale: Amnestic episodes with confusion and wandering could indicate dissociative fugue but also raise concern for neurocognitive disorders such as delirium or dementia.

items.text: My seven-year-old still wets the bed at least three times a week, despite having no medical problems.
items.rationale: Repeated involuntary urination during sleep in a child over age 5 without a medical condition defines enuresis.

items.text: He repeatedly passes stool in inappropriate places, such as his clothing or the floor, at least once a month.
items.rationale: Repeated passage of feces in inappropriate places in a child over age 4 is the defining criterion for encopresis.

items.text: She has never been consistently dry at night — at age nine, she still needs pull-ups every single night.
items.rationale: Primary nocturnal enuresis (never achieved continence) persisting well beyond age 5 is a classic presentation.

items.text: The pediatrician confirmed there is no urinary tract infection or other medical explanation for his bedwetting.
items.rationale: Ruling out medical causes is a necessary diagnostic step; this confirms the functional nature of enuresis.

items.text: He was dry for over a year and then started wetting the bed again after his parents' divorce.
items.rationale: Secondary enuresis (relapse after a period of continence) often follows psychosocial stressors.

items.text: She soils her underwear during the day at school and seems unaware or unbothered by it.
items.rationale: Daytime fecal soiling with apparent lack of awareness is a presentation of encopresis.

items.text: His encopresis is associated with chronic constipation and overflow incontinence, according to his gastroenterologist.
items.rationale: Encopresis with constipation and overflow incontinence is the most common subtype and is specified in DSM-5.

items.text: The wetting happens both during the day and at night, and it's been going on for at least six months.
items.rationale: Diurnal and nocturnal enuresis persisting for the required duration meets full diagnostic criteria.

items.text: She is deeply embarrassed about the bedwetting and refuses to go to sleepovers or camp because of it.
items.rationale: Functional impairment and social avoidance due to enuresis demonstrate clinically significant distress.

items.text: He deliberately defecates in inappropriate places, and there is no evidence of constipation or medical cause.
items.rationale: Encopresis without constipation, sometimes intentional, is a recognized DSM-5 subtype.

items.text: The behavior has been occurring at least twice a week for the past three months in a child who is six years old.
items.rationale: Meeting the frequency (twice weekly for three months) and age criteria confirms the diagnosis of enuresis.

items.text: Multiple medical tests including urinalysis and imaging have come back normal, yet the wetting persists.
items.rationale: Normal medical workup supports a functional (non-organic) elimination disorder diagnosis.

items.text: He has started having accidents at school and seems more anxious and withdrawn than usual.
items.rationale: Elimination accidents with anxiety and withdrawal suggest enuresis/encopresis but the emotional symptoms could indicate a comorbid anxiety disorder.

items.text: She wets herself when she's very frightened or upset, but is otherwise continent.
items.rationale: Stress-induced incontinence could be enuresis but might also be a physiological stress response or related to an anxiety disorder.

items.text: He soils himself and also has frequent angry outbursts and refuses to comply with any household rules.
items.rationale: Encopresis is present, but the oppositional behavior pattern raises the question of comorbid oppositional defiant disorder or conduct disorder.

items.text: I restrict my food intake severely because I'm terrified of gaining weight, even though everyone says I'm dangerously thin.
items.rationale: Restriction of energy intake leading to significantly low body weight with intense fear of gaining weight defines anorexia nervosa.

items.text: I go through cycles of eating enormous amounts of food in one sitting and then making myself vomit to prevent weight gain.
items.rationale: Recurrent binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting is the hallmark of bulimia nervosa, purging type.

items.text: I eat large quantities of food rapidly until I feel uncomfortably full, and afterward I feel disgusted and deeply ashamed.
items.rationale: Recurrent binge eating with marked distress, eating rapidly, and feeling disgusted afterward are DSM-5 criteria for binge eating disorder.

items.text: My entire self-worth is based on my weight and body shape — if the scale goes up even a pound, my whole day is ruined.
items.rationale: Self-evaluation unduly influenced by body weight and shape is a core cognitive feature of anorexia and bulimia nervosa.

items.text: She has been eating non-food substances like chalk and dirt for over a month, despite being old enough to know better.
items.rationale: Persistent eating of non-nutritive, non-food substances defines pica.

items.text: He regurgitates his food, re-chews it, and either re-swallows or spits it out — this has been happening daily for weeks.
items.rationale: Repeated regurgitation of food that may be re-chewed, re-swallowed, or spit out defines rumination disorder.

items.text: I avoid eating most foods because of their texture, smell, or appearance — my diet is limited to about five items.
items.rationale: Avoidance based on sensory characteristics of food leading to nutritional deficiency is consistent with avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID).

items.text: I use laxatives after every meal because I'm desperate to get rid of the calories before my body absorbs them.
items.rationale: Misuse of laxatives as a compensatory behavior is a purging method seen in bulimia nervosa.

items.text: I exercise for three or four hours every day, even when I'm injured or sick, because I can't tolerate the thought of not burning calories.
items.rationale: Excessive compulsive exercise as a compensatory behavior is commonly associated with anorexia and bulimia nervosa.

items.text: My BMI is 14 and I've lost my menstrual period, but when I look in the mirror I still see myself as overweight.
items.rationale: Severely low BMI, amenorrhea, and body image distortion are classic features of anorexia nervosa.

items.text: I eat in secret because I'm ashamed of how much I consume — I hide wrappers and eat only when no one is around.
items.rationale: Eating alone due to embarrassment about quantity consumed is a DSM-5 criterion for binge eating disorder.

items.text: She has significant nutritional deficiencies and has required tube feeding because she simply won't eat enough, though she has no concern about body image.
items.rationale: Failure to meet nutritional needs without body image disturbance distinguishes ARFID from anorexia nervosa.

items.text: I feel completely out of control when I'm eating — I can't stop even when I want to.
items.rationale: Loss of control over eating is central to binge eating, but the subjective experience of loss of control could also overlap with impulse-control difficulties.

items.text: I've been skipping meals and losing weight, but it's mostly because I just don't have any appetite or interest in food.
items.rationale: Appetite loss and weight loss could indicate ARFID or a depressive disorder; the absence of body image concern makes the differential ambiguous.

items.text: I obsessively count every calorie and weigh myself multiple times a day, and I feel intense anxiety if I can't do these rituals.
items.rationale: Ritualistic calorie counting and weighing with anxiety when prevented could map to an eating disorder or to OCD-spectrum anxiety with food-related obsessions.

items.text: I have felt since early childhood that my body does not match who I really am inside — I was assigned male at birth but I know I am female.
items.rationale: A marked incongruence between experienced gender and assigned sex persisting from childhood is the core of gender dysphoria.

items.text: I experience intense distress about my primary and secondary sex characteristics and have a strong desire to be rid of them.
items.rationale: Distress about one's sex characteristics and desire to be rid of them are DSM-5 criteria for gender dysphoria in adolescents and adults.

items.text: She insists that she is a boy, prefers to be called by a male name, and becomes very upset when required to wear girls' clothing.
items.rationale: A strong insistence on being the other gender with distress about gender-typical clothing describes gender dysphoria in children.

items.text: I have a strong desire to have the primary and secondary sex characteristics of a gender different from my assigned sex.
items.rationale: Desire for sex characteristics of another gender is a specific DSM-5 criterion for gender dysphoria.

items.text: I want to be treated as and recognized by others as the gender I identify with, not the one I was assigned at birth.
items.rationale: A strong desire to be treated as the experienced gender is a DSM-5 criterion for gender dysphoria.

items.text: He has expressed a strong conviction that he has the typical feelings and reactions of a girl since he was four years old.
items.rationale: A strong conviction of having feelings typical of the other gender in a young child is a DSM-5 criterion for gender dysphoria in children.

items.text: Looking at my body in the mirror causes me significant distress because it doesn't reflect who I truly am.
items.rationale: Distress related to incongruence between physical body and gender identity is a hallmark of gender dysphoria.

items.text: I have been living as my identified gender for years and am seeking hormone therapy to align my body with my identity.
items.rationale: Seeking medical transition to align physical characteristics with experienced gender is a common clinical presentation of gender dysphoria.

items.text: She consistently chooses male playmates, prefers rough-and-tumble play, and strongly rejects any feminine toys or activities.
items.rationale: Strong preference for cross-gender playmates and activities with rejection of gender-typical ones is a DSM-5 criterion for gender dysphoria in children.

items.text: The incongruence between my gender identity and my assigned sex has caused me clinically significant distress and impaired my social functioning.
items.rationale: Clinically significant distress or impairment associated with gender incongruence is required for the DSM-5 diagnosis.

items.text: I have fantasized about having a different body since puberty, and the development of secondary sex characteristics made my distress much worse.
items.rationale: Pubertal onset or worsening of distress about sex characteristics is a common developmental trajectory in gender dysphoria.

items.text: He repeatedly states that he wants to be a girl and draws pictures of himself as female, becoming upset when corrected.
items.rationale: Repeated verbal expression of desire to be another gender with distress when identity is not affirmed is characteristic of gender dysphoria in children.

items.text: I feel deeply uncomfortable in social situations where I'm expected to conform to the gender role associated with my birth sex.
items.rationale: Discomfort with assigned gender role is consistent with gender dysphoria but could also reflect broader gender nonconformity without clinically significant distress.

items.text: I sometimes feel disconnected from my body and wish it were different, though I'm not sure exactly what I want it to look like.
items.rationale: Body disconnection with vague desire for change could suggest gender dysphoria but also overlaps with depersonalization or body image issues in eating disorders.

items.text: I hate my body and feel like it doesn't represent who I am — I avoid mirrors and feel disgusted by my appearance.
items.rationale: Body dissatisfaction and avoidance of mirrors could indicate gender dysphoria but also maps strongly to body dysmorphic concerns or eating disorder-related body image disturbance.

items.text: Since starting the new antipsychotic, I've developed involuntary repetitive movements of my tongue and jaw that I can't control.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Involuntary orofacial movements following antipsychotic use are characteristic of tardive dyskinesia.

items.text: Within hours of receiving the injection, his muscles became extremely rigid, he developed a high fever, and his consciousness became altered.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and altered consciousness after neuroleptic administration describe neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

items.text: I can't stop pacing and fidgeting — I feel an unbearable inner restlessness ever since my medication was increased.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Subjective restlessness with inability to sit still following medication change is characteristic of akathisia.

items.text: After starting the medication, she developed a sustained, painful twisting of her neck to one side that wouldn't release.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Acute dystonic reaction (sustained muscle contraction) following medication initiation is a classic medication-induced movement disorder.

items.text: He has developed a pill-rolling tremor in both hands since his dopamine-blocking medication was started.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Medication-induced parkinsonism with resting tremor is a well-recognized adverse effect of dopamine antagonists.

items.text: My psychiatrist says the involuntary lip-smacking and tongue movements may be permanent even if we stop the medication.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Potentially irreversible orofacial dyskinesias are the hallmark of tardive dyskinesia from long-term antipsychotic use.

items.text: When I abruptly stopped my antidepressant, I experienced brain zaps, dizziness, nausea, and intense irritability.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Antidepressant discontinuation syndrome with characteristic 'brain zaps' and autonomic symptoms is a recognized adverse medication effect.

items.text: She walks with a shuffling gait and has reduced arm swing — her neurologist attributes it entirely to her psychiatric medication.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Shuffling gait and reduced arm swing are parkinsonian features attributable to dopamine-blocking medications.

items.text: I developed severe muscle stiffness and cogwheel rigidity within days of starting the new antipsychotic.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Cogwheel rigidity and muscle stiffness are cardinal signs of medication-induced parkinsonism.

items.text: The medication caused my eyes to roll upward involuntarily and get stuck — it was terrifying and happened suddenly.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Oculogyric crisis (involuntary upward eye deviation) is a form of acute dystonia caused by dopamine-blocking agents.

items.text: Since the dose increase, I've gained thirty pounds, my blood sugar has spiked, and I feel sedated all the time.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Metabolic syndrome (weight gain, hyperglycemia) and sedation are well-documented adverse effects of atypical antipsychotics.

items.text: He developed uncontrollable jerking movements of his limbs that his doctor confirmed are a side effect of his current medication regimen.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Involuntary limb movements confirmed as medication-related represent a medication-induced movement disorder.

items.text: I feel an intense need to keep moving my legs, especially at night, and it started right after my medication was changed.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Restless leg-like symptoms after medication change suggest akathisia, but could overlap with primary restless legs syndrome.

items.text: I've been trembling and feeling stiff since my medication was adjusted, but I'm not sure if it's the medication or just anxiety.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Tremor and stiffness temporally related to medication change suggest medication-induced parkinsonism, but the patient's uncertainty introduces ambiguity with anxiety-related tremor.

items.text: I can't sit still and I feel an overwhelming inner restlessness — I'm not sure if it's my anxiety getting worse or a side effect of my medication.
items.expected_factor: Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication
items.rationale: Akathisia and anxiety-driven restlessness are phenomenologically similar; this item could map to either medication-induced movement disorders or anxiety disorders.

items.text: I keep forgetting where I put things and I got lost driving to a store I've been going to for twenty years.
items.rationale: Progressive memory loss and spatial disorientation in familiar environments are hallmark symptoms of major neurocognitive disorder (dementia).

items.text: He can no longer manage his finances, cook meals, or remember to take his medications without assistance.
items.rationale: Decline in ability to perform instrumental activities of daily living indicates major neurocognitive disorder.

items.text: I struggle to find the right words in conversation — I know what I want to say but the words just won't come out.
items.rationale: Word-finding difficulties (anomia) represent decline in the language domain of neurocognitive functioning.

items.text: She no longer recognizes her own children and frequently mistakes her daughter for her deceased sister.
items.rationale: Prosopagnosia and misidentification of familiar people indicate severe decline in perceptual-motor and social cognition domains.

items.text: His personality has changed dramatically — he was always reserved and polite, but now he makes inappropriate sexual comments and has no filter.
items.rationale: Personality change with disinhibition and loss of social propriety is characteristic of frontotemporal neurocognitive disorder.

items.text: I was in the hospital and didn't know where I was, what day it was, or why I was there — my awareness kept fluctuating throughout the day.
items.rationale: Fluctuating awareness with disorientation to place and time describes delirium, classified under neurocognitive disorders in DSM-5.

items.text: He has vivid visual hallucinations of small animals in his room, and his alertness and cognition fluctuate dramatically from hour to hour.
items.rationale: Visual hallucinations with fluctuating cognition and alertness are core features of neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies.

items.text: I can't plan or organize anything anymore — even making a simple grocery list feels overwhelming and confusing.
items.rationale: Decline in executive function (planning, organizing) is a key neurocognitive domain affected in major neurocognitive disorder.

items.text: After the stroke, he has difficulty recognizing objects by sight even though his vision tests are normal.
items.rationale: Visual agnosia following cerebrovascular event represents decline in the perceptual-motor domain due to vascular neurocognitive disorder.

items.text: She repeats the same questions and stories within minutes, with no awareness that she has already said them.
items.rationale: Repetitive questioning with no recall of recent statements indicates severe impairment in learning and memory.

items.text: His neuropsychological testing shows a significant decline from his previous level of functioning in attention, memory, and processing speed.
items.rationale: Documented decline across multiple cognitive domains on formal testing is the objective basis for diagnosing neurocognitive disorder.

items.text: I notice I'm a bit slower at processing information and I occasionally forget appointments, but I can still manage everything independently.
items.rationale: Modest cognitive decline that does not interfere with independence in daily activities defines mild neurocognitive disorder.

items.text: I've been having trouble concentrating and my memory isn't what it used to be — I'm worried something is wrong with my brain.
items.rationale: Subjective cognitive complaints could indicate early neurocognitive disorder but also occur in depression, anxiety, and normal aging.

items.text: He seems confused and disoriented at times, and his family says his thinking has gotten noticeably worse over the past year.
items.rationale: Progressive confusion and cognitive decline reported by informants suggest neurocognitive disorder, but could also reflect medication effects or depression.

items.text: I can't remember things and I have no motivation or energy — everything feels foggy and I can't think clearly.
items.rationale: Cognitive fog with memory complaints and amotivation could indicate neurocognitive disorder but also strongly suggests pseudodementia of depression.

items.text: I have always had difficulty reading, even though I tried hard in school and had adequate instruction.
items.rationale: Specific learning disorder in reading is a core neurodevelopmental condition with onset in the developmental period.

items.text: People tell me I fidget constantly and can never seem to sit still in meetings or at dinner.
items.rationale: Hyperactivity and restlessness are hallmark features of ADHD, a neurodevelopmental disorder.

items.text: As a child, I didn't start speaking until much later than other kids my age.
items.rationale: Delayed speech milestones are characteristic of language disorders and intellectual developmental disorders.

items.text: I find it extremely hard to organize tasks and frequently lose important things like my keys, wallet, or phone.
items.rationale: Disorganization and frequently losing items are core inattentive symptoms of ADHD.

items.text: Ever since I was young, I've had involuntary movements and sounds that I can't fully control.
items.rationale: Motor and vocal tics with childhood onset are defining features of Tourette's disorder / tic disorders.

items.text: I have trouble understanding social cues—I often miss sarcasm and take things very literally.
items.rationale: Deficits in social communication and pragmatic language are core features of autism spectrum disorder.

items.text: My teachers always said I was smart, but my math skills were far below what was expected for my grade level.
items.rationale: A discrepancy between general ability and specific academic skill points to specific learning disorder in mathematics.

items.text: I've had a stutter for as long as I can remember, and it gets worse when I'm under pressure.
items.rationale: Childhood-onset fluency disorder (stuttering) is classified among neurodevelopmental communication disorders.

items.text: I become very distressed by small changes in my daily routine and prefer to do things in exactly the same order every day.
items.rationale: Insistence on sameness and inflexible adherence to routines are core restricted/repetitive behavior features of ASD.

items.text: I was diagnosed with an intellectual disability as a child and have always needed extra support with everyday tasks.
items.rationale: Intellectual developmental disorder with deficits in adaptive functioning is a primary neurodevelopmental condition.

items.text: I often blurt out answers before people finish their questions, and I frequently interrupt conversations.
items.rationale: Impulsivity manifesting as interrupting and blurting out is a core symptom of ADHD, combined or hyperactive-impulsive presentation.

items.text: I have an intense, all-consuming interest in train schedules that I've maintained since childhood.
items.rationale: Highly restricted, fixated interests that are abnormal in intensity are a diagnostic criterion for autism spectrum disorder.

items.text: I can never seem to finish projects—I start with enthusiasm but lose focus before completing anything.
items.rationale: Difficulty sustaining attention and following through on tasks is consistent with ADHD but could also reflect motivational issues in mood disorders.

items.text: I've always been clumsy and had poor handwriting that made school very frustrating.
items.rationale: Motor coordination difficulties suggest developmental coordination disorder, though clumsiness can appear in other conditions.

items.text: I need things arranged in a very specific way and get extremely anxious if someone moves my belongings.
items.rationale: Insistence on sameness could reflect ASD restricted behaviors, but ordering and arranging is also a hallmark of OCD.

items.text: I spend hours each day checking that the doors are locked and the stove is off, even though I know I already checked.
items.rationale: Repetitive checking rituals driven by doubt are a classic compulsion in OCD.

items.text: I have intrusive, unwanted thoughts about harming someone I love, even though I would never act on them.
items.rationale: Ego-dystonic intrusive violent obsessions are a well-recognized symptom presentation of OCD.

items.text: I pull out my hair so frequently that I have noticeable bald patches I try to hide.
items.rationale: Trichotillomania (hair-pulling disorder) is classified within the OC-related disorders category.

items.text: I pick at my skin compulsively until it bleeds, and I can't seem to stop even though it leaves scars.
items.rationale: Excoriation (skin-picking) disorder is a recognized OC-related disorder involving recurrent skin picking causing lesions.

items.text: I wash my hands so many times a day that my skin is raw and cracked.
items.rationale: Excessive hand washing driven by contamination obsessions is one of the most common OCD presentations.

items.text: I am preoccupied with the idea that a part of my body is ugly or deformed, even though others say they don't see anything wrong.
items.rationale: Body dysmorphic disorder, characterized by preoccupation with perceived flaws in appearance, is an OC-related disorder.

items.text: I cannot throw anything away, and my home is so cluttered that I can barely move through the rooms.
items.rationale: Hoarding disorder, with persistent difficulty discarding possessions and resultant clutter, is classified as an OC-related disorder.

items.text: I have to count to a certain number or repeat a phrase silently before I can walk through a doorway.
items.rationale: Counting and repeating rituals are classic compulsions in OCD.

items.text: I spend hours arranging objects until they feel 'just right,' and if they're disturbed I have to start over.
items.rationale: Symmetry and ordering compulsions driven by a 'just right' feeling are a well-documented OCD symptom dimension.

items.text: I am terrified that if I don't perform my rituals, something terrible will happen to my family.
items.rationale: Magical thinking linking rituals to harm prevention is a core feature of OCD obsessions and compulsions.

items.text: I check my appearance in mirrors dozens of times a day and compare my features to other people's constantly.
items.rationale: Mirror checking and comparing are repetitive behaviors characteristic of body dysmorphic disorder.

items.text: I have persistent, distressing thoughts about contamination that I know are irrational but I can't dismiss.
items.rationale: Contamination obsessions with insight into their irrationality are a hallmark of OCD.

items.text: I feel compelled to mentally review every conversation I've had to make sure I didn't say something offensive.
items.rationale: Mental reviewing can be an OCD mental compulsion, but rumination about social interactions also occurs in social anxiety disorder.

items.text: I avoid touching doorknobs and public surfaces because I'm afraid of getting seriously ill.
items.rationale: Contamination avoidance is common in OCD but could also reflect illness anxiety or specific phobia.

items.text: I worry constantly that I might have a serious disease, and I repeatedly check my body for signs of illness.
items.rationale: Repetitive body checking and health preoccupation could be OCD (somatic obsessions) or somatic symptom/illness anxiety disorder.

items.text: My therapist says my relationship difficulties are a major focus of our treatment, even though I don't have a formal psychiatric diagnosis.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Relationship problems as a focus of clinical attention without a formal mental disorder diagnosis fall under V/Z codes.

items.text: I am seeking help primarily because of the stress of caring for my elderly parent with dementia.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Caregiver burden is a recognized V/Z code condition that may be a focus of clinical attention.

items.text: I came to the clinic because I was recently the victim of a violent crime and need support.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Victim of crime is a condition listed under other conditions that may be a focus of clinical attention.

items.text: My main concern right now is that I'm having trouble adjusting after losing my job and I'm not sure how to cope.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Occupational problems and economic difficulties are V/Z code conditions warranting clinical attention.

items.text: I'm here because my doctor wants me to get help with following my treatment plan for diabetes—I keep skipping my medication.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Nonadherence to medical treatment is a recognized condition that may be a focus of clinical attention.

items.text: I grew up in foster care and experienced significant neglect as a child, which still affects me today.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Child neglect history is coded under other conditions that may be a focus of clinical attention.

items.text: I'm struggling because my spouse and I are going through a bitter divorce and it's affecting every part of my life.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Disruption of family by separation or divorce is a relational V/Z code condition.

items.text: I'm seeking counseling because I recently found out I was adopted and I'm having an identity crisis.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Phase of life problems and identity issues not attributable to a mental disorder are V/Z code conditions.

items.text: I'm homeless right now and that's the main reason I'm having trouble functioning—I just need stability.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Homelessness and housing instability are coded as other conditions that may be a focus of clinical attention.

items.text: My partner is physically abusive, and I need help figuring out how to stay safe.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Spouse or partner violence is a V/Z code condition that may be a focus of clinical attention.

items.text: I'm a veteran and I'm having a hard time readjusting to civilian life after deployment.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Phase of life problems related to military-to-civilian transition are V/Z code conditions, distinct from PTSD.

items.text: I feel like I'm faking being well—I deliberately exaggerated my symptoms to get disability benefits.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Malingering is classified under other conditions that may be a focus of clinical attention.

items.text: I've been feeling really down and hopeless since my divorce was finalized three months ago.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Could be a relational V/Z code problem or could meet criteria for adjustment disorder or major depressive episode.

items.text: I have a lot of conflict with my teenage son, and it's the main reason I'm seeking help.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: Parent-child relational problem is a V/Z code, though the conflict could also stem from a diagnosable disorder in either party.

items.text: Ever since the assault, I have nightmares every night and I can't stop thinking about what happened.
items.expected_factor: Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
items.rationale: While the assault is a V/Z code condition, the nightmares and intrusive thoughts strongly suggest PTSD, a trauma-related disorder.

items.text: I become sexually aroused primarily by watching unsuspecting people undress without their knowledge.
items.rationale: Voyeuristic disorder involves recurrent sexual arousal from observing unsuspecting persons who are undressing or engaged in sexual activity.

items.text: I have persistent and intense sexual urges involving exposing my genitals to strangers.
items.rationale: Exhibitionistic disorder is defined by recurrent, intense sexually arousing fantasies or urges involving genital exposure to unsuspecting persons.

items.text: I can only become sexually aroused when I am rubbing against a non-consenting person in a crowded place.
items.rationale: Frotteuristic disorder involves recurrent sexual arousal from touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person.

items.text: I experience intense, recurrent sexual fantasies about inflicting physical suffering on another person.
items.rationale: Sexual sadism disorder involves recurrent, intense sexually arousing fantasies involving the suffering of another person.

items.text: I need to be humiliated, beaten, or otherwise made to suffer in order to achieve sexual gratification.
items.rationale: Sexual masochism disorder involves recurrent sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, or otherwise made to suffer.

items.text: I have recurrent, intense sexual urges directed toward prepubescent children that cause me significant distress.
items.rationale: Pedophilic disorder involves recurrent, intense sexually arousing fantasies or urges involving prepubescent children.

items.text: I can only achieve sexual arousal by wearing clothing typically associated with the opposite sex.
items.rationale: Transvestic disorder involves recurrent, intense sexual arousal from cross-dressing that causes distress or impairment.

items.text: I have an intense and exclusive sexual fixation on a specific non-living object, such as shoes, that I require for arousal.
items.rationale: Fetishistic disorder involves recurrent, intense sexual arousal from nonliving objects or specific non-genital body parts.

items.text: I have acted on my sexual urges toward non-consenting individuals on multiple occasions.
items.rationale: Acting on paraphilic urges with non-consenting persons is a key criterion for several paraphilic disorder diagnoses.

items.text: I practice autoerotic asphyxiation regularly because restricting my breathing during sex is the only way I can climax.
items.rationale: Asphyxiophilia is a form of sexual masochism involving restriction of breathing for sexual arousal.

items.text: My sexual fantasies about non-consenting partners have been present since adolescence and have never diminished.
items.rationale: Persistent paraphilic interests with onset in adolescence and a non-consenting focus are characteristic of paraphilic disorders.

items.text: I have been arrested more than once for indecent exposure because I cannot control my urge to expose myself.
items.rationale: Repeated legal consequences from acting on exhibitionistic urges strongly indicate exhibitionistic disorder.

items.text: I find that I need increasingly extreme sexual scenarios to become aroused, and this pattern worries me.
items.rationale: Escalating need for extreme sexual stimulation suggests paraphilic interests, though it could also reflect general sexual compulsivity.

items.text: I have sexual fantasies that I find deeply shameful and that I've never told anyone about.
items.rationale: Shame about sexual fantasies may indicate paraphilic interests, but shame alone is nonspecific and could relate to cultural factors.

items.text: I have intense sexual urges that I struggle to control, and they have led to serious problems in my relationships and with the law.
items.rationale: Uncontrollable sexual urges causing legal and relational problems could indicate a paraphilic disorder or could reflect impulsivity seen in personality disorders (e.g., antisocial PD).

items.text: I have an intense fear of abandonment and will go to extreme lengths to prevent people from leaving me.
items.rationale: Frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment are a core criterion of borderline personality disorder.

items.text: I have a long pattern of exploiting others for my own gain without feeling guilty about it.
items.rationale: Interpersonal exploitation and lack of remorse are hallmark features of antisocial and narcissistic personality disorders.

items.text: I feel empty inside almost all the time, and my relationships are incredibly intense and unstable.
items.rationale: Chronic emptiness and a pattern of unstable, intense relationships are core features of borderline personality disorder.

items.text: I don't really have any close friends and I prefer it that way—I have no interest in social relationships.
items.rationale: Lack of desire for close relationships and emotional detachment are defining features of schizoid personality disorder.

items.text: People have always told me I have an inflated sense of my own importance and that I expect special treatment.
items.rationale: Grandiosity and sense of entitlement are core criteria for narcissistic personality disorder.

items.text: I am extremely suspicious of other people's motives and I assume they are trying to harm or deceive me.
items.rationale: Pervasive distrust and suspiciousness are the defining features of paranoid personality disorder.

items.text: I have a lifelong pattern of disregarding rules and violating the rights of others without remorse.
items.rationale: Pervasive disregard for and violation of others' rights is the central feature of antisocial personality disorder.

items.text: I need constant reassurance from others before I can make even minor decisions in my daily life.
items.rationale: Difficulty making everyday decisions without excessive advice and reassurance is a core feature of dependent personality disorder.

items.text: I avoid social situations and new activities because I'm certain people will criticize or reject me.
items.rationale: Avoidance of interpersonal contact due to fears of criticism and rejection is central to avoidant personality disorder.

items.text: I am so preoccupied with details, rules, and lists that I often lose sight of the main point of an activity.
items.rationale: Preoccupation with details, rules, and order to the extent that the major point is lost is a criterion for obsessive-compulsive personality disorder.

items.text: I use dramatic, exaggerated emotional displays to get attention, and I feel uncomfortable when I'm not the center of it.
items.rationale: Excessive emotionality and attention-seeking are defining features of histrionic personality disorder.

items.text: I have odd beliefs and magical thinking that influence my behavior—for example, I believe I can sense events before they happen.
items.rationale: Magical thinking and odd beliefs are characteristic of schizotypal personality disorder.

items.text: I've cut or burned myself on purpose many times when I felt overwhelmed by my emotions.
items.rationale: Recurrent self-harm is strongly associated with borderline personality disorder, though it can also occur in other conditions.

items.text: I tend to see people as either completely wonderful or completely terrible, with no middle ground.
items.rationale: Splitting (idealization and devaluation) is characteristic of borderline PD but can also appear in narcissistic PD and other conditions.

items.text: I sometimes hear a voice commenting on my actions when I'm under extreme stress, but it goes away quickly.
items.rationale: Transient, stress-related quasi-psychotic experiences can occur in borderline and schizotypal PD but also suggest schizophrenia spectrum disorders.
items.boundary_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

items.text: I hear voices that other people cannot hear, and they often comment on my behavior or argue with each other.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Auditory hallucinations, especially commenting or conversing voices, are a hallmark positive symptom of schizophrenia.

items.text: I am convinced that the government has implanted a tracking device in my body, even though no one believes me.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Persecutory and bizarre delusions are core positive symptoms of schizophrenia and delusional disorder.

items.text: My thoughts feel jumbled and I often can't organize them well enough to have a coherent conversation.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Disorganized thinking manifesting as incoherent speech is a cardinal feature of schizophrenia.

items.text: I believe that messages on television and radio are directed specifically at me.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Ideas of reference—believing that external events have special personal significance—are characteristic of psychotic disorders.

items.text: I have lost all motivation to do anything—I don't care about work, hobbies, or seeing friends anymore.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Avolition and social withdrawal are prominent negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

items.text: People tell me my face shows no emotion and my voice is flat, even when I'm talking about something important.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Diminished emotional expression (flat affect) is a core negative symptom of schizophrenia.

items.text: I sometimes stand in unusual postures for long periods of time and resist being moved by others.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Catatonic posturing and rigidity are recognized features of catatonia associated with schizophrenia spectrum disorders.

items.text: I believe that other people can read my thoughts or that my thoughts are being broadcast aloud.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Thought broadcasting is a Schneiderian first-rank symptom strongly associated with schizophrenia.

items.text: I had a sudden episode where I believed I was a prophet with a divine mission, and it lasted about two weeks before resolving completely.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: A brief psychotic episode with grandiose delusions lasting less than one month is consistent with brief psychotic disorder.

items.text: I see things that aren't there—shadowy figures or flashes of light—and it happens almost every day.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Recurrent visual hallucinations are a positive psychotic symptom seen in schizophrenia spectrum disorders.

items.text: I feel that an outside force is controlling my body movements and making me do things against my will.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Delusions of control (passivity experiences) are first-rank symptoms characteristic of schizophrenia.

items.text: My speech often goes off on tangents and people say they can't follow what I'm trying to say.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Tangential and derailed speech reflects formal thought disorder, a core feature of schizophrenia.

items.text: I've become increasingly isolated over the past year and I barely speak to anyone, even my family.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Progressive social withdrawal is consistent with the negative symptoms of schizophrenia but could also reflect severe depression or avoidant PD.

items.text: I have a persistent belief that my neighbor is poisoning my food, even though there is no evidence for it.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: A non-bizarre persecutory delusion could indicate delusional disorder or schizophrenia; the distinction depends on other symptoms.

items.text: I have unusual perceptual experiences—I sometimes feel like my body is changing shape or that things look unreal.
items.expected_factor: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders
items.rationale: Unusual perceptual experiences and derealization could indicate schizotypal personality disorder or a dissociative disorder rather than a full psychotic disorder.

items.text: I have persistent difficulty achieving or maintaining an erection sufficient for sexual activity, and it causes me significant distress.
items.rationale: Erectile disorder is a well-defined sexual dysfunction in the DSM-5 characterized by difficulty obtaining or maintaining erections.

items.text: I almost never experience any sexual desire or interest in sexual activity, and this has been the case for over six months.
items.rationale: Absent or reduced interest in sexual activity is the core feature of female sexual interest/arousal disorder or male hypoactive sexual desire disorder.

items.text: I consistently ejaculate within one minute of penetration, and it happens almost every time, causing me great frustration.
items.rationale: Premature (early) ejaculation is defined by a persistent pattern of ejaculation occurring within approximately one minute.

items.text: I experience significant pain during intercourse that is not explained by any medical condition.
items.rationale: Genito-pelvic pain during intercourse is a core feature of genito-pelvic pain/penetration disorder.

items.text: Despite adequate stimulation and desire, I am unable to reach orgasm, and this has been a persistent problem.
items.rationale: Marked delay in, infrequency of, or absence of orgasm is the defining feature of female orgasmic disorder or delayed ejaculation.

items.text: I have a marked difficulty with vaginal penetration due to involuntary tightening of the pelvic floor muscles.
items.rationale: Involuntary pelvic floor muscle contraction preventing penetration is a feature of genito-pelvic pain/penetration disorder.

items.text: I find it very difficult to become physically aroused during sexual activity, even when I feel emotionally interested.
items.rationale: Absent or reduced physical arousal despite psychological interest is characteristic of female sexual interest/arousal disorder.

items.text: It takes me an extremely long time to ejaculate—sometimes over 30 minutes of continuous stimulation—and often I cannot at all.
items.rationale: Delayed ejaculation is characterized by marked delay in or inability to achieve ejaculation despite adequate stimulation.

items.text: My sexual difficulties have been present since my very first sexual experiences and have never improved.
items.rationale: Lifelong subtype of sexual dysfunction indicates the disturbance has been present since the individual's first sexual experiences.

items.text: I feel intense anxiety and dread about sexual encounters because I'm afraid of the pain I'll experience.
items.rationale: Marked fear or anxiety about vulvovaginal or pelvic pain in anticipation of intercourse is a criterion for genito-pelvic pain/penetration disorder.

items.text: My lack of sexual desire is causing serious conflict in my marriage and I feel terrible about it.
items.rationale: Clinically significant distress and interpersonal difficulty due to low desire are required for diagnosis of hypoactive sexual desire disorder.

items.text: I used to have a normal sex life, but after starting my new medication, I completely lost my ability to become aroused.
items.rationale: Substance/medication-induced sexual dysfunction is a recognized DSM-5 diagnosis when sexual dysfunction is attributable to medication effects.

items.text: I've noticed a gradual decline in my sexual interest over the past year, and I'm not sure if it's related to my depression.
items.rationale: Decreased libido can be a symptom of sexual dysfunction or a feature of major depressive disorder; differential diagnosis is needed.

items.text: I avoid intimacy with my partner because I'm worried about my sexual performance.
items.rationale: Performance anxiety is commonly associated with sexual dysfunctions but could also reflect social anxiety or relationship problems.

items.text: Since I started drinking heavily, I've had increasing difficulty with sexual performance, but I'm not sure which problem came first.
items.rationale: Sexual dysfunction co-occurring with heavy alcohol use could be substance-induced sexual dysfunction or a primary substance use disorder with secondary effects.

items.text: I fall asleep at inappropriate times during the day, even in the middle of conversations or while driving.
items.rationale: Excessive daytime sleepiness with irresistible sleep attacks is the hallmark of narcolepsy and hypersomnolence disorder.

items.text: I have been told that I stop breathing repeatedly during sleep, and I wake up gasping for air.
items.rationale: Recurrent episodes of upper airway obstruction during sleep are the defining feature of obstructive sleep apnea hypopnea.

items.text: I walk around the house while fully asleep and have no memory of it the next morning.
items.rationale: Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is a non-REM sleep arousal disorder classified under sleep-wake disorders.

items.text: I have terrifying episodes where I wake up screaming in a panic but can't remember what frightened me.
items.rationale: Sleep terrors are a non-REM sleep arousal disorder characterized by abrupt awakening with intense fear and autonomic arousal.

items.text: I lie awake for hours every night unable to fall asleep, and it's been going on for months.
items.rationale: Persistent difficulty initiating sleep is the core feature of insomnia disorder.

items.text: I have an irresistible urge to move my legs at night, especially when I'm trying to rest, and it keeps me from sleeping.
items.rationale: Restless legs syndrome is a sleep-wake disorder characterized by an urge to move the legs, typically worse at rest and in the evening.

items.text: I act out my dreams physically—I've punched, kicked, and even fallen out of bed while asleep.
items.rationale: REM sleep behavior disorder involves loss of normal REM atonia with dream enactment behaviors.

items.text: My sleep schedule is completely out of sync with the rest of the world—I naturally fall asleep at 4 AM and wake at noon.
items.rationale: Delayed sleep phase type of circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder involves a persistent delay in the sleep-wake cycle.

items.text: I experience sudden episodes of muscle weakness triggered by strong emotions like laughter, and I sometimes collapse.
items.rationale: Cataplexy—sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by emotions—is pathognomonic for narcolepsy type 1.

items.text: I have vivid, frightening hallucinations just as I'm falling asleep or waking up.
items.rationale: Hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations are associated features of narcolepsy.

items.text: I wake up multiple times during the night and then can't get back to sleep, leaving me exhausted during the day.
items.rationale: Difficulty maintaining sleep with frequent awakenings is a core presentation of insomnia disorder.

items.text: Working rotating night shifts has completely disrupted my sleep, and I can never seem to adjust.
items.rationale: Shift work type circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder results from a work schedule that overlaps the usual sleep period.

items.text: I sleep over 10 hours a night and still feel unrefreshed and excessively sleepy during the day.
items.rationale: Excessive sleep with unrefreshing quality suggests hypersomnolence disorder, though hypersomnia also occurs in depression.

items.text: I have recurring nightmares that wake me up in a cold sweat and make it hard to go back to sleep.
items.rationale: Nightmare disorder is a sleep-wake disorder, but recurrent nightmares are also a prominent feature of PTSD.

items.text: I can't sleep at all without taking a sleeping pill, and I've been increasing my dose because it's not working as well anymore.
items.rationale: Insomnia requiring escalating doses of medication could indicate insomnia disorder or could reflect substance tolerance and a developing substance use disorder.

items.text: I am constantly worried that I have a serious illness, even though multiple doctors have told me I'm healthy.
items.rationale: Illness anxiety disorder is characterized by preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious illness despite minimal or no somatic symptoms.

items.text: I have chronic pain in multiple parts of my body that doctors cannot explain with any medical tests.
items.rationale: Somatic symptom disorder involves distressing somatic symptoms with excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to them.

items.text: I spend an excessive amount of time and energy worrying about my health symptoms, and it dominates my daily life.
items.rationale: Disproportionate and persistent thoughts about the seriousness of one's symptoms are a core criterion of somatic symptom disorder.

items.text: I suddenly lost the ability to move my legs, but neurological exams show nothing wrong with my nervous system.
items.rationale: Conversion disorder (functional neurological symptom disorder) involves neurological symptoms incompatible with recognized neurological conditions.

items.text: I frequently visit different doctors seeking an explanation for my symptoms, but I'm never satisfied with their reassurances.
items.rationale: Doctor shopping and persistent dissatisfaction with medical reassurance are behavioral features of somatic symptom and illness anxiety disorders.

items.text: I have episodes where I appear to have seizures, but EEG monitoring shows no epileptic activity.
items.rationale: Psychogenic non-epileptic seizures are a presentation of conversion disorder (functional neurological symptom disorder).

items.text: I deliberately made myself sick by taking too much of a medication so that I would be admitted to the hospital.
items.rationale: Factitious disorder imposed on self involves deliberate falsification or induction of illness to assume the sick role.

items.text: I have been experiencing numbness and tingling in my hands that my doctor says has no medical explanation.
items.rationale: Medically unexplained sensory symptoms are consistent with conversion disorder or somatic symptom disorder.

items.text: I am so anxious about my health that I constantly research diseases online and convince myself I have them.
items.rationale: Excessive health-related behaviors such as repeated internet searching are a criterion for illness anxiety disorder.

items.text: I have difficulty swallowing that comes and goes, and medical tests have found no physical cause.
items.rationale: Functional dysphagia without organic cause is a recognized presentation of conversion disorder.

items.text: I have been told that I exaggerate my child's symptoms to doctors, and child protective services has been called.
items.rationale: Factitious disorder imposed on another (Munchausen by proxy) involves falsification of illness in another person.

items.text: My physical symptoms get significantly worse whenever I'm under emotional stress.
items.rationale: Psychological factors affecting other medical conditions and somatic symptom disorder both involve stress-symptom relationships.

items.text: I have persistent headaches that no medication seems to help, and I've seen many specialists without finding a cause.
items.rationale: Persistent medically unexplained headaches suggest somatic symptom disorder, though primary headache disorders should be ruled out.

items.text: I feel like my body is falling apart, and I can't stop thinking about all the things that might be wrong with me.
items.rationale: Catastrophic thinking about bodily symptoms is consistent with somatic symptom disorder but could also reflect health anxiety in OCD or generalized anxiety.

items.text: I have intrusive, repetitive thoughts about having cancer that I can't get out of my head, and I check my body for lumps dozens of times a day.
items.rationale: Repetitive body checking and intrusive health-related thoughts could indicate illness anxiety disorder or OCD with somatic obsessions.

items.text: I can't stop drinking even though it has cost me my job, my marriage, and my health.
items.rationale: Continued use despite significant social, occupational, and health consequences is a core criterion of alcohol use disorder.

items.text: I need to take much more of the drug than I used to in order to get the same effect.
items.rationale: Tolerance—needing increased amounts to achieve the desired effect—is a diagnostic criterion for substance use disorders.

items.text: When I try to stop using, I get shaking, sweating, nausea, and sometimes even seizures.
items.rationale: Physiological withdrawal symptoms upon cessation are a hallmark criterion of substance use disorders.

items.text: I spend most of my day either obtaining drugs, using them, or recovering from their effects.
items.rationale: A great deal of time spent in activities necessary to obtain, use, or recover from a substance is a DSM-5 criterion for substance use disorders.

items.text: I've tried to cut back on my gambling many times, but I always end up going back to the casino.
items.rationale: Gambling disorder is classified under substance-related and addictive disorders, and repeated unsuccessful efforts to control gambling is a criterion.

items.text: I keep using opioids even though my doctor warned me it's destroying my liver.
items.rationale: Continued substance use despite knowledge of a persistent physical problem caused or exacerbated by the substance is a core criterion.

items.text: I often end up using much more cocaine than I originally intended to.
items.rationale: Taking a substance in larger amounts or over a longer period than intended is a diagnostic criterion for substance use disorders.
