items.text: I have given up playing sports and seeing my friends because all I want to do is drink.
items.rationale: Giving up important social, occupational, or recreational activities because of substance use is a DSM-5 criterion.

items.text: I have strong cravings for methamphetamine that are so intense I can think of nothing else.
items.rationale: Craving or a strong desire to use a substance is a diagnostic criterion for substance use disorders in DSM-5.

items.text: I continue to use marijuana even though it's causing serious arguments with my family and problems at work.
items.rationale: Continued use despite persistent social or interpersonal problems caused or exacerbated by the substance is a criterion for cannabis use disorder.

items.text: I've been chasing my gambling losses by betting more and more money, and now I'm deeply in debt.
items.rationale: Chasing losses is a specific diagnostic criterion for gambling disorder.

items.text: I've driven while intoxicated on multiple occasions, even after getting a DUI.
items.rationale: Recurrent substance use in physically hazardous situations is a criterion for substance use disorders.

items.text: I feel restless and irritable whenever I try to cut down on my drinking.
items.rationale: Irritability and restlessness when reducing use suggest withdrawal, but these symptoms are nonspecific and could reflect anxiety or mood disorders.

items.text: I started using painkillers after a surgery and now I feel like I can't function without them.
items.rationale: Iatrogenic opioid dependence is common, but distinguishing between physiological dependence and a full use disorder requires further assessment.

items.text: I use alcohol every night to help me fall asleep because otherwise I lie awake for hours.
items.rationale: Using alcohol as a sleep aid could indicate alcohol use disorder or could primarily reflect an underlying insomnia disorder with self-medication.

items.text: I have recurring nightmares about a terrible event that happened to me, and I wake up feeling like it's happening all over again.
items.rationale: Recurrent distressing dreams with content related to a traumatic event are a core re-experiencing symptom of PTSD.

items.text: I go out of my way to avoid places, people, or situations that remind me of something traumatic that happened to me.
items.rationale: Persistent avoidance of external reminders of the traumatic event is a hallmark criterion of PTSD.

items.text: Ever since the event, I feel emotionally numb — like I can't experience love, joy, or closeness with anyone.
items.rationale: Persistent inability to experience positive emotions and emotional numbing are negative alterations in cognition and mood associated with PTSD.

items.text: I am constantly on edge and scanning my surroundings for danger, even when I know I'm in a safe place.
items.rationale: Hypervigilance is a core arousal and reactivity symptom in PTSD diagnostic criteria.

items.text: Sometimes I suddenly feel or act as if the traumatic event is actually happening again right now — I lose track of where I really am.
items.rationale: Dissociative flashback episodes in which the individual feels or acts as if the event is recurring are a defining re-experiencing symptom of PTSD.

items.text: After a major life change, I developed problems with sleep, concentration, and anxiety that made it hard to function at work or school.
items.rationale: Marked distress and functional impairment following an identifiable stressor are central to Adjustment Disorder diagnosis.

items.text: I blame myself for what happened, even though other people tell me it wasn't my fault — I can't shake the guilt.
items.rationale: Persistent distorted cognitions about the cause or consequences of the traumatic event leading to self-blame are a DSM-5 PTSD Criterion D symptom.

items.text: I startle very easily now — a sudden loud noise or someone coming up behind me can send me into a panic.
items.rationale: Exaggerated startle response is a specific hyperarousal criterion for PTSD in the DSM-5.

items.text: There are important parts of the traumatic event that I simply cannot remember, no matter how hard I try.
items.rationale: Inability to remember important aspects of the traumatic event (dissociative amnesia) is a Criterion D symptom of PTSD.

items.text: Since the trauma, I have lost interest in activities that used to matter a lot to me — nothing feels meaningful anymore.
items.rationale: Markedly diminished interest or participation in significant activities is a negative alteration in cognition and mood criterion for PTSD.

items.text: I have angry outbursts that seem to come out of nowhere, and they started after the traumatic experience.
items.rationale: Irritable behavior and angry outbursts with little or no provocation are an arousal and reactivity symptom of PTSD linked to the traumatic event.

items.text: When I encounter something that reminds me of the trauma — a smell, a sound, a scene — I experience intense psychological distress and physical reactions like a racing heart.
items.rationale: Intense or prolonged psychological distress and marked physiological reactions to cues resembling the traumatic event are core re-experiencing symptoms.

items.text: After my divorce, I felt overwhelmed and tearful for months and had trouble keeping up with daily responsibilities, which was very unlike me.
items.rationale: This describes emotional and behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor consistent with Adjustment Disorder, though the depressive features could also suggest a Major Depressive Episode.

items.text: I sometimes feel detached from my own body or like I'm watching myself from the outside, especially when I'm reminded of what happened.
items.rationale: Depersonalization triggered by trauma reminders is consistent with the dissociative subtype of PTSD, but depersonalization can also occur in Dissociative Disorders or Depersonalization/Derealization Disorder independently.

items.text: I lie awake most nights with a mind that won't stop racing, and I feel a persistent sense of dread about the future that I can't connect to any specific event.
items.rationale: Sleep disturbance and persistent dread could reflect PTSD hyperarousal, but the absence of a clearly identified traumatic event and the generalized, free-floating nature of the anxiety more closely resembles Generalized Anxiety Disorder.
